HYOSCINE HYDROBROMIDE

ANTIMUSCARINICS (SYSTEMIC)

  • Indications and doses
  • Pregnancy
  • Hepatic impairment
  • Renal impairment
  • Administration
  • Patient and carer advice
  • Important safety information
  • Cautions
  • Unlicensed use
  • Prescribing and dispensing
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Motion sickness,

By transdermal application

  • For adults
    150–300 micrograms, dose to be taken up to 30 minutes before the start of journey, then 150–300 micrograms every 6 hours if required; maximum 900 micrograms per day.
  • For adults
    Apply 1 patch, apply behind ear 5–6 hours before journey, then apply 1 patch after 72 hours if required, remove old patch and site replacement patch behind the other ear.
  • For children 4–9 years
    75–150 micrograms, dose to be taken up to 30 minutes before the start of journey, then 75–150 micrograms every 6 hours if required; maximum 3 doses per day.
  • For children 10–17 years
    150–300 micrograms, dose to be taken up to 30 minutes before the start of journey, then 150–300 micrograms every 6 hours if required; maximum 900 micrograms per day.
  • For children 10–17 years
    Apply 1 patch, apply behind ear 5–6 hours before journey, then apply 1 patch after 72 hours if required, remove old patch and site replacement patch behind the other ear.

Hypersalivation associated with clozapine therapy,

By mouth

  • For adults
    300 micrograms up to 3 times a day; maximum 900 micrograms per day.

Excessive respiratory secretion (in palliative care),

By continuous subcutaneous infusion

  • For adults
    400 micrograms every 4 hours as required, hourly use is occasionally necessary, particularly in excessive respiratory secretions.
  • For adults
    1.2–2 mg/24 hours.

Bowel colic in palliative care,

By subcutaneous infusion

  • For adults
    400 micrograms every 4 hours as required, hourly use is occasionally necessary.
  • For adults
    1.2–2 mg/24 hours.

Bowel colic pain in palliative care,

By mouth

  • For adults
    300 micrograms 3 times a day, as Kwells .

Premedication,

By subcutaneous injection or by intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    200–600 micrograms, to be administered 30–60 minutes before induction of anaesthesia.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Use only if potential benefit outweighs risk. Injection may depress neonatal respiration.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Use with caution.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Use with caution.

Directions for administration

With topical use in children

Patch applied to hairless area of skin behind ear; if less than whole patch required either cut with scissors along full thickness ensuring membrane is not peeled away or cover portion to prevent contact with skin.

With oral use in children

For administration by mouth, injection solution may be given orally.

Advice for patients and carers

With transdermal use

Explain accompanying instructions to patient and in particular emphasise advice to wash hands after handling and to wash application site after removing, and to use one patch at a time.

Important safety information

Antimuscarininc drugs used for premedication to general anaesthesia should only be administered by, or under the direct supervision of, personnel experienced in their use.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Epilepsy
  • With systemic use in adults:

    In some patients, especially the elderly, hyoscine may cause the central anticholinergic syndrome (excitement, ataxia, hallucinations, behavioural abnormalities, and drowsiness).

  • With systemic use in children:

    In some children hyoscine may cause the central anticholinergic syndrome (excitement, ataxia, hallucinations, behavioural abnormalities, and drowsiness).

Unlicensed use

In children

Not licensed for use in excessive respiratory secretions or hypersalivation associated with clozapine therapy.

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

Flavours of chewable tablet formulations may include raspberry.

Prepared medicinal forms of HYOSCINE HYDROBROMIDE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: eye drops, oral suspension, oral solution,
Tablet
Chewable tablet
Solution for injection
Transdermal patch
